questions.text: In JVP which of the following coincides with isovolumetric contraction phase of the heart?
questions.solution:
After the atrial systole, the atria starts to relax, indicated by the x descent in the JVP. Isovolumetric contraction occurs after that, where the AV valves are closed. The tricuspid valve bulges into the atria and causes the c wave. It correlates with S1

Isovolumetric contraction is followed by ventricular systole, where the pressure inside the ventricles exceed the Aortic and pulmonary pressure and the semilunar valves open and the ventricles contract. The AV valves remain closed. The atria continue to relax and get filled by the venous return. This results in v wave in JVP.

Ventricular systole is followed by ventricular diastole. During isovolumetric relaxation, the pressure inside the great vessels start falling and to prevent back flow the semilunar valves close, the AV valves continue to remain closed.

The pressure inside the ventricles continue to fall and the AV valves open and the ventricles start filling passively. After the passive filling, the atria contracts and ejects blood into the ventricles, which is represented by a wave in the JVP. It correlates with S4.

questions.text: Which congenital disease has equal saturation in all four chambers of the heart?
questions.solution: Total anomalous pulmonary venous connections (TAPVC) is a cyanotic congenital heart disease where all of the pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly open into the right atrium. O2 saturation of blood in the pulmonary artery is often identical to that in aorta due to complete mixing of systemic and pulmonary venous returns in the right atrium.

questions.text: Which of the following causes hypokalemia with metabolic alkalosis and hypertension?
questions.solution:
Tubular function defects that lead to hypokalemia with alkalosis are-

Liddle syndrome, Bartter Syndrome and Gittleman syndrome. However, Liddle syndrome causes Hypertension, whereas as Barter and Gitleman syndrome causes normotensive or low BP.

Liddle's syndrome is caused by autosomal dominant gain-in-function mutations of ENaC subunits. Disease-associated mutations either activate the channel directly or abrogate aldosterone-inhibited retrieval of ENaC subunits from the plasma membrane; the end result is increased expression of activated ENaC channels at the plasma membrane of principal cells. Patients with Liddle's syndrome classically manifest severe hypertension with hypokalemia.

Loss of the transport functions of the TALH causes Bartter syndrome. Patients with classic BS typically suffer from polyuria and polydipsia, due to the reduction in renal concentrating ability. They may have an increase in urinary calcium excretion, and 20% are hypomagnesemic. Other features include marked activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis. Patients with antenatal BS suffer from a severe systemic disorder characterized by marked electrolyte wasting, polyhydramnios, and hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis; renal prostaglandin synthesis and excretion are significantly increased, accounting for much of the systemic symptoms. There are five disease genes for BS, all of them functioning in some aspect of regulated Na+, K+, and Cl- transport by the TALH.

Loss of transport function at DCT causes Gitelman Syndrome. GS is genetically homogeneous, caused almost exclusively by loss-of-function mutations in the thiazide-sensitive Na+-Cl- cotransporter of the DCT. Patients with GS are uniformly hypomagnesemic and exhibit marked hypocalciuria, rather than the hypercalciuria typically seen in BS; urinary calcium excretion is thus a critical diagnostic test in GS. GS is a milder phenotype than BS; however, patients with GS may suffer from chondrocalcinosis, an abnormal deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) in joint cartilage.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred drug treatment in the treatment of primary progressive multiple sclerosis?

A 60 year old postmenopausal woman came with reports of DEXA scan which showed a t score of -2.5. She had a history of colles fracture 6 months back which was fixed. She is not a smoker and does not consume alcohol. Which of the following is correct about her further management?
questions.solution: The patient is a post menopausal female with t score of -2.5, with a past history of Colles fracture, is an indication for anti resorptive treatment. The anti-resorptive agent in the given option is alendronate.

questions.text: In a 35 year female patient with grade 2 primary pulmonary hypertension the vasoreactivity test was negative. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Negative vasoreactive test in young patients without any high risk factors, treatment with combination oral agents is considered. This includes Endothelin receptor antagonists and Phosphodiesterase inhibitors.

choices.text: In recent time there is an in case of HCC
NAFLD AND NASH progress to HCC
Lenvatinib is used for HCC treatment when lesion is less than 3 cms
TACE is routinely done for small lesions of HCC.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding hepatocellular carcinoma except
questions.solution: Lenvatinib is used for the treatment of advanced HCC. For lesions less than 3 cm, either liver transplantation or TACE is preferred.

questions.text: All of the following cause splenomegaly except
questions.solution: Organomegaly and lymphadenopathy are absent in Aplastic anemia.

choices.text: B, C and D are correct

questions.text:
A patient presented with an episode of TIA. On examination he was found to have an irregularly irregular pulse. A 2d echo showed he had severe mitral stenosis. ECG showed atrial fibrillation. Which of the following is true regarding prevention of stroke.
A. Aspirin is the only drug needed
B. Warfarin is indicated
C. NOACs are not indicated
D. Patient with MS can be recommended for a mitral valve surgery
questions.solution: Warfarin is the anticoagulant of choice in valvular AF, For patients with AF or atrial flutter and an elevated CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or greater in men or 3 or greater in women, anticoagulation with warfarin (INR 2.0-3.0), is recommended.

questions.text: A 19 year old presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breast development and secondary sexual maturation was normal. Pubic and axillary hair growth were also normal. USG showed an absent uterus. Most likely diagnosis is

choices.text: Patient is euvolemic and at times hypervolemic

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding SIADH?
questions.solution: The syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) is a disorder of impaired water excretion caused by the inability to suppress the secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). In SIADH, the urine sodium excretion is high. Hyponatremia (ie, serum Na+< 135 mmol/L) with concomitant hypo-osmolality (serum osmolality < 280 mOsm/kg) and high urine osmolality are the hallmark of SIADH.

choices.text: EEG is required for diagnosis of Epilepsy
Scalp eeg is used for diagnosis of frontal lobe seizures
In progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy the EEG shows rhythmic spikes and diffuse slow wave pattern
10% of normal people show epileptic activity

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements except?
questions.solution:
• The EEG is always abnormal during generalized tonic-clonic
  • The absence of electrographic seizure activity does not exclude a seizure disorder, however, because focal seizures may originate from regions of the cortex that cannot be detected by standard scalp electrodes.
  • EEG may also be helpful in the interictal period by showing certain abnormalities that are highly supportive of the diagnosis of epilepsy. Such epileptiform activity consists of bursts of abnormal discharges containing spikes or sharp waves. The presence of epileptiform activity is not entirely specific for epilepsy, but it has a much greater prevalence in patients with epilepsy than in other individuals. However, even in an individual who is known to have epilepsy, the initial routine interictal EEG may be normal 50-80% of the time. Thus, the EEG has limited sensitivity and cannot establish the diagnosis of epilepsy in many cases.
  • Focal interictal epileptiform discharges would support the diagnosis of a focal seizure disorder such as temporal lobe epilepsy or frontal lobe seizures, depending on the location of the discharges
  • The routine scalp-recorded EEG may also be used to assess the prognosis of seizure disorders; in general, a normal EEG implies a better prognosis, whereas an abnormal background or frequent epileptiform activity suggests a worse outcome. Unfortunately, the EEG has not proved to be useful in predicting which patients with predisposing conditions such as head injury or brain tumor will go on to develop epilepsy, because in such circumstances epileptiform activity is commonly encountered regardless of whether seizures occur.
  • Magnetoencephalography (MEG) provides another way of looking noninvasively at cortical activity. Instead of measuring electrical activity of the brain, it measures the small magnetic fields that are generated by this activity. The epileptiform activity seen on MEG can be analyzed, and its source in the brain can be estimated using a variety of mathematical techniques. These source estimates can then be plotted on an anatomic image of the brain such as an MRI (discussed below) to generate a magnetic source image (MSI). MSI can be useful to localize potential seizure foci.

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as when BP control is not occurring with use of 3 drugs. Among these, which of the following drug patients has to be on to meet the definition?
questions.solution: The term resistant hypertension refers to patients with blood pressures persistently >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic.

choices.text: Inhibits the RNA dependent RNA polymerase

questions.text: Remdesivir's mechanism of action is
questions.solution: Remdesivir inhibits RNA dependent RNA polymerase of SARS and MERS CoV.

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis presents with ascites and pedal edema. For mobilization of edema fluid what is the preferred diuretic?
questions.solution: In patients with cirrhosis, ascites is treated with spironolactone. Furosemide is added if peripheral edema is present.

questions.text: As per IAS DP the proposed single step testing with a 75 gram oral glucose for gestational diabetes, the fasting glucose cut off is
questions.solution:
It is recommended that an FPG( Fasting plasma glucose) value in early pregnancy ≥5.1 mmol/l (92 mg/dl) should also be classified as Gestational Diabetes Mellitus.

International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups Consensus Panel; Metzger BE, Gabbe SG, Persson B, Buchanan TA, Catalano PA, Damm P, Dyer AR, Leiva Ad, Hod M, Kitzmiller JL, Lowe LP, McIntyre HD, Oats JJ, Omori Y, Schmidt MI. International association of diabetes and pregnancy study groups recommendations on the diagnosis and classification of hyperglycemia in pregnancy.

questions.text: Eye hand coordination is mainly by which lobe of the brain?
questions.solution: Activities related to visuospatial orientation are controlled by the posterior parietal cortex.

questions.text: In hepatitis B vaccine the following subunit is most vital?
questions.solution:
The main component of Hepatitis B vaccine is the surface antigen. Current regimens use recombinant vaccines containing the surface antigen.

Another recombinant hepatitis B vaccine with a novel adjuvant that activates Toll-like 9 receptors was approved for adults aged 18 or older. In a series of prospective trials, compared to three Engerix-B injections, two IM doses a month apart yielded higher proportions with protective levels of anti-HBs (≥10 mIU/mL): 95% of adults aged 18-55 or 18-70 (vs 81% for Engerix-B), 90% of older adults aged 40-70 (vs 71% for Engerix-B), and 90% of adults aged 18-70 with type 2 diabetes (vs 65% for Engerix-B). This two-injection regimen may be useful for revaccination of persons who failed to respond to the original vaccines.

Another novel recombinant vaccine (PreHevbrio, VBI Vaccines) containing of all three hepatitis B surface antigens, S, pre-S1, and pre-S2, has been shown in clinical trials (three IM doses at 0, 1, and 6 months) to achieve higher proportions with protective anti-HBs and higher antibody levels than Engerix-B (which contains S antigen only), including in older persons (≥45 years), persons with diabetes, and overweight persons (body mass index >30)

questions.text: A 60 year old patient presented with fatigue and lymphadenopathy, PBS showed smudge cells. What should be the next step in management?
questions.solution: Smudge cells are seen in CLL. If peripheral blood counts are high flow cytometry can be used to identify B cell markers CD19, 20.

questions.text: A boy presents with fever, night sweats and neck swelling. Biopsy of the swelling showed a starry sky appearance. The gene responsible is
questions.solution: Starry sky appearance is seen in Burkitt's lymphoma. Burkitt's lymphoma is associated with translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8. The usual translocations are (2,8), (8,14), (8,22).

questions.text: Acute treatment of cluster headache
questions.solution:
The treatment of acute episodes of cluster headache is Oxygen inhalation @10l/min. Since it is not in the options, the next best option would be Sumatriptan SC.

Sumatriptan 6 mg SC is rapid in onset and will usually shorten an attack to 10-15 min; there is no evidence of tachyphylaxis. Sumatriptan (20 mg) and zolmitriptan (5 mg) nasal sprays are both effective in acute cluster headache, offering a useful option for patients who may not wish to self-inject daily. Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) is FDA approved for the acute treatment of attacks in episodic cluster headache using three 2-min stimulation cycles applied consecutively at the onset of headache on the side of pain; this may be repeated after 9 min.

Oral sumatriptan is not effective for prevention or for acute treatment of cluster headache.
